ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR: OTH 37402 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PROPOSED 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
(Financed by the Gender and Development Cooperation Fund) 
 
FOR 
 
PROMOTING GENDER EQUALITY AND WOMEN’S EMPOWERMENT  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
November 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CSP  –  country strategy and program 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EA  –  executing agency 
  GAD  –  gender and development 
  M&E  –  monitoring and evaluation 
  MDG  –  Millennium Development Goals 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  RSDD  –  Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
  RSPR  –  Poverty Reduction and Social Development Division 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Lateef.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In  1998  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  adopted  its  policy  on  gender  and 
development (GAD).1 The policy and related ADB-wide action plan2 promote gender equity as a 
crosscutting strategy in all aspects of ADB’s operations. In 1999 ADB adopted poverty reduction 
as its overarching objective.3 ADB’s enhanced focus on poverty reduction underscores the 
importance of mainstreaming gender, since gender equity is recognized as a key factor in 
transforming growth into development and ni   reducing  poverty.  ADB's  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) need assistance to narrow gender gaps and to meet the internationally 
endorsed  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  virtually  all  of  which  have  gender 
dimensions. 
  
2.  The current challenge is to more closely align ADB’s poverty reduction initiatives with 
gender equality goals and MDGs. Additional resources are required to support new approaches 
and  strategic  initiatives  linking  poverty  and  gender,  and  to  realign  initiatives  to  meet  the 
challenges of the MDGs. In May 2003 ADB’s Board of Directors approved the establishment of 
the Gender and Development Cooperation Fund. It is intended to support a coherent program of 
activities to strengthen the capacity of ADB and DMC governments to (i) mainstream gender 
considerations into their policies, programs and projects; (ii) support innovative and strategic 
approaches to narrow gender gaps and empower women and girls; and (iii) promote regional 
awareness, partnerships, and cooperation on gender issues. This proposed regional technical 
assistance (TA) will launch the program.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB recently prepared an interim progress report on implementing the GAD policy,5  
which was submitted to the Board of Directors in 2002. The report shows that, since approval of 
the GAD policy, ADB has substantially increased its GAD activities since the pre-policy period. 
However, the report also reveals that this progress has been uneven and that much work 
remains to be done to consistently implement the GAD policy and action plan. 
 
4.  For example, gender strategies are being prepared in conjunction with country strategies 
and programs (CSPs), but considerable variation exists in the depth of analysis and integration 
of gender concerns in the main text of the CSP. Similar variations are found in the attention to 
gender in recent country poverty assessments and poverty reduction partnership agreements 
between ADB and individual DMCs. Gender specialists need to be included in teams preparing 
the  CSPs  and  carrying  out  country  poverty  assessments  to  ensure  integration  of  gender 
concerns and attention to gender-related MDGs. 
  
5.  Preparation of loans that directly promote gender equality and the empowerment of 
women and girls, as well as loans that mainstream gender concerns, should be improved. More 
loans that have GAD as a thematic objective and mainstream gender issues are required.

Project-specific gender plans also need to be prepared for more loans to ensure gender-
inclusive design and implementation. 
 
6.  The GAD action plan also includes a limited number of grant-based initiatives for GAD 
capacity-building in national women’s ministries and executing agencies (EAs) in selected 
DMCs, as well as regional TA grants in areas such as gender and governance, and combating 
trafficking of women and girls. Although a small proportion of ADB’s overall TA, these activities 
need to be continued and expanded, particularly in capacity building for GAD within DMCs.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
7.  The proposed TA will help ADB more consistently and effectively implement its GAD 
policy  and  action  plan.  The  TA  will  also  help  key  government  agencies  in  DMCs  more 
systematically  address  gender  concerns  in  planning,  development,  and  implementation  of 
programs and projects to reduce gender disparities and meet the MDGs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The proposed TA includes the following fund approved categories of activities under the 
program. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
9.  CSP Activities. ADB’s GAD policy recognizes that gender mainstreaming has to begin 
with development of CSPs, which provide the medium-term frameworks for ADB’s assistance to 
its DMCs. Unless gender issues are adequately addressed at this “upstream” stage, it is unlikely 
that the ensuing pipeline of assistance will promote gender equality and the empowerment of  
women. The systematic integration of gender concerns in CSPs requires the preparation of 
gender strategies to define how ADB’s program of assistance to the DMC will address gender 
disparities and promote gender equity. This component will selectively finance preparation of 
gender strategies and other selective upstream work to integrate gender in national poverty 
reduction strategies and CSPs, and to realign ADB’s loan and TA portfolios with the MDGs. 
Possible activities in this area include (i) gender assessments of selected government policies 
and  programs;  (ii)  gender  inputs  to  sector  strategies  and  roadmaps;  and  (iii)  support  for 
development  of  more  gender-sensitive  macroeconomic  frameworks,  planning  and  budget 
processes, and poverty monitoring systems.  
 
10.  Gender Plans and Other Support for ADB Loans. The GAD policy and action plan 
include commitments to increase the number of ADB loans that (i) promote gender equity and 
empower  women  and  girls,  and  (ii)  more  effectively  mainstream  gender  concerns.  Some 
progress in these areas was noted in the progress report, including development of gender 
plans for individual loan projects. However, additional resources are needed to replicate good 
practices in more loan projects. Therefore, this component will finance (i) the development of 
gender plans for a larger number of loan projects, for more DMCs, and in a wider range of 
sectors; and (ii) other strategic GAD support for loan projects.  
 
11.  Recent ADB experience has shown the benefits of project-specific gender plans that 
include targets, gender-inclusive design elements, specific budget allocations, and gender-
specific indicators for monitoring to ensure effective gender mainstreaming. Funds will be 
provided under this component to include gender experts in loan preparation teams to help

3 
conduct  gender  analysis  and  prepare  project-specific  gender  plans.  These  plans  will  be 
incorporated in project documents and covenanted to ensure their implementation. Projects with 
high potential for gender-inclusive design and for replication of good practices developed in 
previous projects will be emphasized. Efforts will be made to ensure that support is given to 
projects in a variety of sectors and subsectors, including infrastructure, small and medium-sized 
enterprise development, and governance and legal reform. 
 
12.  Country and local conditions need to be taken into account in identifying gender issues 
and gender gaps, and in developing effective strategies to promote gender equity in particular 
projects. In many instances, loan projects may require a social preparation phase or special 
features to facilitate women’s participation and equitable access to loan inputs. For instance, 
women members of water users’ associations may need training to understand the association 
bylaws or to participate effectively in the association, or women may need to be mobilized to 
access extension services and other inputs from an agriculture or rural development project. 
Hence, this component will finance strategic interventions in conjunction with loan projects to 
prepare  women  or  to  help  them  fully  participate  in  loan  project  activities.  Interventions 
associated with loan projects to address issues such as prevention of trafficking in women and 
children, violence against women, and the impact of industrial restructuring on women workers 
will be supported. In many instances, these initiatives will be more effectively conducted by 
women’s nongovernment organizations (NGOs) with experience in these areas but need to be 
linked to larger government loan projects for greater impact.  
 
13.  GAD Capacity Building. Limited technical capacity for gender analysis and planning, 
within ADB and in DMCs, seriously hinders the development and implementation of gender-
responsive loan projects and programs, and any increase in ADB activities focusing on gender 
equality and empowering women and girls. To make progress in these areas, and to fulfill the 
commitments made in ADB’s GAD action plan, this subcomponent will support capacity building 
of (i) national women’s ministries and other focal agencies in DMCs, and (ii) EAs in ADB-
supported sectors of DMCs.  
 
14.  For several years, ADB has been providing TA to national women’s ministries and other 
focal agencies to help develop and implement GAD policy and undertake gender capacity 
building.  Most  recently,  this  support  has  been  provided  in  Fiji,  Indonesia,  Lao  People's 
Democratic Republic, Pakistan and Viet Nam.  These strategic GAD activities are crucial to 
promote and institutionalize gender mainstreaming in DMCs. This subcomponent will provide 
funds to continue and expand these activities, including selective support to ministries of women 
for more strategic planning; promotion of gender audits and gender-responsive budgeting; and 
integration  of  gender  concerns  in  national  poverty  reduction  strategies,  and  governance 
programs, especially in the context of decentralization.6  
 
15.  EAs  have  limited  gender  technical  capacity,  which  hinders  effective  gender 
mainstreaming, even in projects designed to address gender-related objectives. This applies 
especially to EAs that are largely infrastructure or engineering oriented, with limited social 
science  skills.  This  subcomponent  will  help  EAs  implement  ADB-financed loans that are 
designed to be gender-inclusive. Activities under this subcomponent may include (i) gender 
training  activities  for  executing  and  implementing  agency  staff;  (ii)  preparation  of  gender 
checklists, good practices, and other materials tailored to the specific country and sector; (iii) 
lateral learning opportunities such as field visits across sectors or within a sector to learn from

other projects; (iv) support to allow project directors from one country to participate as resource 
persons for training in another; (v) gender training for DMC officials, especially from ministries of 
finance or planning; and (vi) preparation of modules for gender training of EA staff who attend 
ADB’s annual project implementation seminars. In light of the limited technical and human 
resource capacity of many EAs, the TA will also provide opportunities to improve links between 
EAs and other actors in the same sector, including community-based women’s groups, NGOs, 
private service providers, and local research institutes.  
 
16.  Gender Impact Assessments. In a variety of sectors, ADB has financed loan projects 
that either have carried a GAD thematic classification or have been designed with effective 
gender  mainstreaming.  Most  of  these  projects  are  under  implementation.  Gender  impact 
assessments will be conducted to estimate the impacts of these loans, the effectiveness of 
gender plans or measures included in the loan designs, implementation constraints, potential for 
improving  design  or  implementation  arrangements,  and  replicability.  These  gender  impact 
assessments will be used to identify midcourse corrections and to prepare materials on good 
practices and lessons learned. This component may finance selective assessments of individual 
loans or loan clusters within a particular sector or DMC.  
 
17.  GAD Partnerships. This component will support activities related to new and emerging 
gender issues in the Asia and Pacific region, as well as ADB’s partnerships with women’s 
organizations, other development partners, and regional networks to promote gender equality 
and empower women. For example, the TA may support joint activities with institutions such as 
the Commonwealth Secretariat, International Labour Organization, International Organization 
for Migration, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Development Fund for 
Women, and World Bank, and bilateral development agencies of ADB’s member countries, to 
support the mainstreaming of gender considerations in national poverty strategies, development 
plans and budget processes, and to address violence against women and gender issues related 
to  HIV/AIDS7  prevention  and  treatment,  conditions  of  migrant  workers,  human  trafficking, 
postconflict reconstruction, and other concerns.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the TA, estimated at $1.5 million, will be financed by the Gender and 
Development Cooperation Fund on a grant basis. Indicative cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB will implement the TA. The Poverty Reduction and Social Development Division 
(RSPR) of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD), in association with 
the regional departments, will be responsible for all TA activities. Subproject concepts may be 
developed by staff in the regional departments, resident missions (RMs) and RSDD, and at the 
suggestion  of  fund  contributors  and  focal  ministries  and  agencies  in  DMCs.  Proposed 
subproject activities will be described in short concept papers, which will be screened initially by 
RSPR and then submitted to an internal peer review committee for endorsement and approval. 
The committee will consist of ADB staff with gender expertise from the regional departments 
and RSPR. A simplified format for subproject proposals will be provided by RSPR to all regional 
departments and RMs following approval of the TA.8

8  Endorsement by the peer review committee will constitute approval of all subproject proposals.

20.  The  department  or  RM  that  submitted  proposals  for  approval  will  implement  the 
subproject in consultation with RSPR and other concerned staff. Subprojects generated by 
departments at ADB headquarters will be implemented in close cooperation with the relevant 
RMs. In all subprojects, strong emphasis will be placed on using local expertise and involving 
civil society, in particular community-based women’s organizations and NGOs, to strengthen the 
capacity of local resource  persons and local institutions. Regional and subregional activities 
may be supported under the TA. Care will be taken to ensure subregional, country, and sector 
balance.  
 
21.  A  TA  office  will  be  established  in  RSPR.  Approximately  24  person-months  of 
international consultants with gender expertise will be needed to coordinate and monitor TA 
activities. One full-time administrator and research assistant, financed by the TA, will support 
the TA team and peer review committee in overall coordination and implementation of the TA. 
Additional short-term international and domestic consultants with gender and other relevant 
expertise will be engaged to implement particular TA activities. Consultants will be recruited as 
individuals. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  acceptable  to  ADB  for  the  recruitment  of  domestic 
consultants will be used to select and engage TA consultants. Any procurement of goods and 
other services for TA activities will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
22.  The TA will be implemented over 38 months, from December 2003 to February 2007. 
RSPR will prepare a consolidated annual report on the TA and the overall program. Selected 
reports will be posted on the GAD page of ADB’s website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
23.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Gender and Development Cooperation Fund for Promoting Gender Equality and Women’s 
Empowerment.

Appendix 3 
    
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  These outline terms of reference for consultants describe the main tasks for international 
and domestic consultants in the categories of activities included in the technical assistance (TA) 
to  help  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  developing  member  country  (DMC) 
governments systematically address gender concerns in their programs and projects. The 
categories of activities for which consulting services are expected to be required are (i) gender 
and development (GAD) support for country strategy and program (CSP) activities; (ii) gender 
plans and other support for ADB loan projects and programs; (iii) GAD capacity building of 
national women’s ministries and executing agencies in ADB-supported sectors; (iv) gender 
impact assessments of selected loan projects and programs; and (v) TA coordination, and 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E). Most of the TA consultants will be recruited as individuals. 
More detailed terms of reference will be  prepared for each consultant or consulting team 
engaged under the TA. 
 
A.  GAD Support for CSP Activities 
 
2.  International and/or domestic gender specialists will be selectively engaged to (i) carry 
out gender analysis, including review of gender-related statistics, participatory assessments and 
consultations  with  government  officials,  women’s  organizations  and  community  groups,  in 
connection with country poverty assessments and preparation of CSPs; (ii) propose gender 
strategies, and provide gender inputs to sector strategies and roadmaps, for CSPs; and (iii) 
carry out in-depth studies on emerging gender issues relevant to ADB’s operations in particular 
DMCs, such as women’s migration, gender-differentiated impacts of economic policy reforms, 
and gender issues within ethnic minority groups.    
 
B.  GAD Support for ADB Loan Projects and Programs 
 
3.  International and/or domestic gender specialists will be selectively engaged to (i) help 
loan project and program design teams conduct gender analysis and prepare project-specific 
gender plans or strategies; (ii) develop and implement strategic interventions in ADB-financed 
loan projects to facilitate women’s participation in project activities (e.g., through training and 
mobilization support); (iii) develop subcomponents of loan projects or grant-based activities 
linked to loan projects to address gender-related issues (e.g., prevention of trafficking in women 
and  children,  violence  against  women,  and  impact  of  industrial  restructuring  on  women 
workers);  and  (iv)  develop  stand-alone  projects  that  demonstrate  innovation  in  promoting 
gender equality and women’s and girls’ empowerment (e.g., in connection with post-conflict 
reconstruction in DMCs such as Afghanistan and Sri Lanka).  
 
4.  Women’s nongovernment organizations may also be engaged under the TA to carry out 
social preparation and supplementary activities developed for ADB-financed loan projects as 
described in para. 3. 
 
C.  GAD Capacity Building 
 
5.  International and/or domestic gender specialists will be selectively engaged to (i) provide 
training and capacity building to national women’s ministries in DMCs (e.g., to promote gender 
audits, gender-sensitive planning, and gender-responsive budgeting); and (ii) provide gender 
training and capacity building to executing and implementing agency staff in ADB-supported 
sectors (e.g., by preparing gender checklists and guidelines relevant to the country and sector,

facilitating exchange visits and other lateral learning experiences, and preparing gender training 
modules for project implementation seminars for project directors and executing agency staff).  
 
D.  Gender Impact Assessments 
 
6.  International and/or domestic gender specialists will be engaged to carry out selective 
gender assessments of individual loans or loan clusters financed by ADB within a particular 
DMC or sector. These assessments will include analysis of (i) the effectiveness of gender-
inclusive provisions or plans in the project design; (ii) implementation constraints and measures 
taken to address them; (iii) effectiveness of the project M&E system in tracking gender-related 
outcomes and impacts; (iv) potential for improving gender-related aspects of the project design 
and implementation; (v) good practices and lessons learned from the project; and (vi) potential 
for replicability of successful project elements in other countries or sectors. 
 
E.  TA Coordination, and Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
7.  An international gender specialist will be engaged to carry out the following tasks in 
support of the coordination and M&E of the TA program: (i) help develop annual work programs 
under the TA in consultation with staff in the Poverty Reduction and Social Development 
Division  (RSPR)  and  with  participating  contributors  to  the  Gender  and  Development 
Cooperation Fund; (ii) help staff in the regional departments and resident missions develop 
proposals for TA activities; (iii) help RSPR staff and the TA peer review committee review and 
process  TA  proposals;  (iv)  develop  targets  and  performance  indicators  for  the  main  TA 
subcomponents,  to  be  included  in  the  annual  work  programs,  monitoring  system  for  TA 
activities, and annual reviews and reports; (v) oversee implementation of TA activities, including 
disbursements and submission of progress and other reports; (vi) supervise the domestic 
administrator/research assistant in preparing and updating material on TA activities for ADB’s 
gender website; and (vii) organize annual reviews of TA activities and prepare annual reports on 
these activities.  
 
8.  A domestic administrator/research assistant will be engaged to carry out the following 
tasks in support of TA coordination and M&E: (i) help the international gender specialist and 
RSPR staff prepare annual work programs under the TA and organize consultations with fund 
contributors; (ii) help the international gender specialist, RSPR staff, and TA peer review 
committee process TA proposals; (iii) establish and maintain a database and monitoring system 
for TA activities and related disbursements and use of funds; (iv) help the international gender 
specialist oversee implementation of TA activities, including disbursements and submission of 
progress and other reports; (v) prepare and update material on TA activities for ADB’s gender 
website; and (vi) help the international gender specialist organize annual reviews of TA activities 
and prepare annual reports on these activities.
